Every person on Earth over the age of sixteen got to vote, and every human over twenty-five was automatically entered as a candidate. It was the ultimate expression of self-governance—we'd make our own gods, thank you very much.

I'd voted in the last four elections, of course. Everyone did. It was considered the most important civic duty in human history. But I'd never seriously considered that I might be chosen. I was a thirty-two-year-old middle school science teacher from the South Side. I recycled religiously, volunteered at the food bank on weekends, and had never gotten so much as a parking ticket. But God? Me?

The previous God, Amara Okafor, had been a brilliant Nigerian philosopher and humanitarian. Before her, it was Dr. James Whitfield, a quantum physicist who'd revolutionized our understanding of consciousness. They were titans of human achievement. I taught eighth-graders about photosynthesis and tried not to cry when budget cuts eliminated the arts program.

My phone buzzed incessantly as news outlets somehow got hold of my number. I turned it off and sat in stunned silence, staring at the mess of broken ceramic and spilled coffee that seemed to perfectly represent my life in this moment.

The thing about being God—as the orientation materials I received made abundantly clear—was that you didn't actually get omnipotence. That would have been too easy, too much like the old myths. Instead, you got something far more terrifying: responsibility without unlimited power. The elected God served as humanity's moral compass, chief counselor, and ultimate decision-maker for the planet's most pressing issues. You had access to every world leader, unlimited resources for humanitarian efforts, and the weight of eight billion people's hopes and prayers on your shoulders.

The previous Gods had tackled climate change, global poverty, and interplanetary colonization efforts. Amara had established the Universal Peace Accords that finally ended the last armed conflicts on Earth. Dr. Whitfield had launched the consciousness preservation project that promised to revolutionize how we understood life and death.

And now they wanted me to follow that?

The flight to Geneva felt surreal. Other passengers kept glancing at me—word had leaked, of course. Some looked awed, others skeptical, a few openly hostile. I overheard someone mutter, "A teacher? Really? That's who's going to guide humanity for the next decade?"

I wondered the same thing.

The Divine Transition Center was a gleaming complex nestled in the Swiss Alps, designed to be as religiously neutral as possible while still inspiring reverence. Amara met me at the entrance, her warm smile doing little to calm my nerves.

"You look terrified," she said, embracing me like an old friend.

"Shouldn't I be?"

She laughed, a sound that somehow managed to be both divine and completely human. "Oh, absolutely. The day you stop being terrified is the day you stop being worthy of the position."

Over the next week, she walked me through the responsibilities. The Global Council meetings where I'd have the final say on international disputes. The daily prayer requests—not the religious kind, but humanity's collective wishes for guidance on everything from personal relationships to corporate ethics. The scientific advisory boards working on humanity's next evolutionary steps. The weight of being the person everyone looked to when they needed hope.

"But why me?" I asked during one of our sessions. "I'm nobody special."

Amara raised an eyebrow. "Eight billion people disagree. Do you know what your campaign materials said? Because you didn't submit any."

I shook my head.

"Nothing. Your name was there with everyone else's, but no platform, no promises, no grand vision for humanity's future. And yet people voted for you in unprecedented numbers. Do you know what that tells me?"

"That they made a mistake?"

"That they're tired of grand visions and brilliant minds. They want someone who understands what it's like to struggle with a broken coffee maker on a Monday morning. Someone who's stood in front of a classroom full of kids who don't want to learn and found a way to make them care anyway. Someone who's lived a real, messy, human life."

Her words settled something in me, though the fear remained.

On my first day as God, I sat in the office that had been occupied by the most influential people of the past five decades. The desk was simple wood, the chair comfortable but not ostentatious. Through the window, I could see the Alps stretching endlessly, a reminder of how small we all were in the grand scheme of things.

My first official prayer request came from a nine-year-old in Mumbai who wanted to know if her grandmother was proud of her in heaven. My first policy decision involved mediating a dispute between the Mars colonies and Earth over resource allocation. My first crisis was a solar storm that threatened global communications.

I thought about my eighth-grade students, how they'd look at me now. I'd always told them that they could be anything, that the future belonged to them. I'd never imagined that the future might belong to their teacher too.

As I prepared for my first address to humanity, I realized something: maybe being God wasn't about having all the answers. Maybe it was about being brave enough to ask the right questions, and humble enough to admit when you didn't know. Maybe it was about remembering that divinity wasn't about perfection—it was about service.

I was still terrified. But for the first time since seeing that notification, I thought I might actually be able to do this job.

After all, I'd been preparing for it my whole life. I just hadn't known it yet.

samples.prompt: Write a story set in our present time. Except make it seem like an unusually prophetic piece of dystopian science-fiction written sometime in the 1970's or earlier. With "world building"descriptions of our society and technology.
samples.output:
**The Glass Watchers**
*A Cautionary Tale of Tomorrow*

The year was 2024, and Marcus Chen held the rectangular glass tablet close to his face, its ethereal blue glow casting shadows across his weathered features. Like all citizens of the Global Democratic Republic, he carried this miraculous device—no larger than a book, yet containing the sum of human knowledge—everywhere he ventured. The Party called it a "smart phone," though Marcus often wondered if it was the device that was smart, or if it had made humanity foolish.

Through his apartment's reinforced polymer windows, he gazed down at the sprawling metropolis below. Millions of souls moved through concrete canyons, each clutching their own glowing tablets, their eyes never lifting to acknowledge one another. The Great Connectivity, as the historians called it, had promised to unite all of humanity in a web of instant communication. Instead, it had created a world of isolated islands, each person marooned in their own digital archipelago.

The morning ritual began as always. Marcus pressed his thumb against the glass surface, and the device recognized his unique biological signature—a security measure the Party had implemented after the Privacy Wars of the early 2000s. Instantly, a cascade of information flooded the screen: messages from the Social Network Collective, updates from the Global News Syndicate, and advertisements precisely tailored to his psychological profile by the great thinking machines housed in distant server farms.

These mechanical brains, built from silicon and electricity, had grown beyond their creators' wildest dreams. They watched, learned, and predicted human behavior with uncanny accuracy. The Party insisted they were merely tools for commerce and convenience, but Marcus remembered his grandfather's warnings about machines that could think. "When man creates a mind greater than his own," the old man had whispered, "he becomes the servant, not the master."

The apartment's climate control system hummed to life, automatically adjusting the temperature based on data collected from sensors embedded in Marcus's clothing. Even his garments had become part of the vast surveillance apparatus. Microscopic transmitters woven into the fabric monitored his heart rate, body temperature, and location at all times. The Party claimed this was for health and safety, part of the Universal Wellness Initiative that had eliminated most diseases through constant biological monitoring.

Marcus's breakfast arrived via the pneumatic delivery system that connected every dwelling to the Central Distribution Hub. The meal had been algorithmically designed based on his genetic profile, dietary restrictions, and the nutritional requirements calculated by the Health Optimization Network. No human hand had touched the food; it was prepared entirely by mechanical servants in sterile factories outside the city.

As he ate, the wall-mounted viewing screen activated automatically, displaying the morning's mandatory information broadcast. The anchorwoman's perfect synthetic features—enhanced through cosmetic biotechnology until she resembled a porcelain doll more than a human being—smiled warmly as she delivered the day's approved news. The Global Climate Management System had successfully prevented another weather catastrophe. The Economic Stability Algorithm had maintained perfect employment through the Universal Basic Income program. The Social Harmony Index showed record levels of citizen satisfaction.

Marcus knew better than to trust these reports entirely. The Party's definition of truth had become fluid, shaped by what the great thinking machines determined would maintain social order. Dissenting voices were not silenced through crude censorship but rather drowned in an ocean of approved content, their messages lost in the algorithmic tide that determined what information each citizen would see.

The commute to his workplace required no human driver. Marcus simply spoke his destination to the autonomous transport pod, and it joined the endless stream of identical vehicles flowing through the city's arteries. Traffic accidents had become extinct, eliminated by the perfect coordination of machine minds that could calculate millions of variables in microseconds. Yet something vital had been lost in this mechanical precision—the chaos, the unpredictability, the essential humanity of a world where people made their own choices, even poor ones.

At the Data Processing Center where Marcus labored, human workers served primarily as biological components in a vast information machine. His task was to review and categorize the endless stream of personal data collected from citizens' devices, purchases, movements, and social interactions. The irony was not lost on him that his job was to help the machines better understand humanity, to feed the very system that was slowly digesting human autonomy.

His colleagues rarely spoke to one another, preferring to communicate through their devices even when sitting mere feet apart. Physical conversation had become awkward, inefficient compared to the precise exchange of digital messages. The art of reading facial expressions, interpreting tone of voice, and understanding the subtle nuances of human emotion was atrophying like an unused muscle.

During his lunch break, Marcus walked through the city's commercial district, past shops where holographic advertisements followed pedestrians, whispering personalized temptations based on their browsing history and psychological profiles. Physical currency had long since vanished, replaced by digital transactions that left perfect records of every purchase, every preference, every moment of weakness or desire.

Children played in the public squares, but their games were mediated by augmented reality systems that overlaid digital fantasies onto the physical world. They chased virtual creatures invisible to the naked eye, their movements tracked and analyzed to optimize their educational programming. The Party had eliminated childhood obesity, academic failure, and social maladjustment through constant monitoring and intervention. Yet Marcus wondered if they had also eliminated childhood itself.

As evening approached, Marcus returned to his apartment, where the artificial intelligence that managed his living space greeted him by name, adjusting lighting and temperature to match his biometric indicators. The system suggested entertainment options based on his mood, recommended social connections based on compatibility algorithms, and even proposed romantic partners through the Optimal Matching Network.

Before sleep, Marcus performed his own small act of rebellion. He turned off his device, closed his eyes, and tried to remember what silence felt like before the constant hum of connectivity filled every moment. In these brief interludes of disconnection, he glimpsed the ghosts of a world that once was—messy, inefficient, dangerous, but undeniably human.

Tomorrow would bring more of the same: perfect efficiency, optimal outcomes, and the gradual erosion of everything that made life worth living. The machines had not conquered humanity through violence or revolution, but through the far more insidious method of making themselves indispensable, one convenience at a time.

samples.prompt: You live in a universe where everyone learns their last words 20 years before they die.
samples.output:
# The Weight of Knowing

The envelope arrived on my fortieth birthday, precisely at midnight, sliding through the mail slot with the soft whisper of inevitability. I'd been waiting for it, of course—we all wait for our Terminus Letter. Twenty years to the day before your death, the universe delivers your final words in crisp, black typography on cream-colored paper. No one knows how it works, only that it always does.

My hands trembled as I tore open the seal. Inside, in elegant script, were four simple words: "I should have tried."

I stared at those words until my coffee grew cold, until the morning sun painted golden rectangles across my kitchen floor, until my neighbor Mrs. Chen knocked to check if I was alright. She'd received her letter thirty years ago—"Tell David I forgive him"—and had spent the intervening decade trying to figure out which David she meant. Her husband? Her estranged brother? The boy who'd broken her heart in college? She'd systematically reached out to every David she'd ever known, offering forgiveness for perceived slights and ancient wounds. When her time came, she wanted to be ready.

That was the thing about the letters—they created two distinct types of people. The Preparers, like Mrs. Chen, spent their remaining years orchestrating their deaths down to the smallest detail, ensuring their final words would make perfect sense. Then there were the Rebels, who fought against their prescribed endings, convinced they could outsmart fate itself.

I'd always assumed I'd be a Rebel. But "I should have tried" felt different from the dramatic final declarations I'd imagined. It wasn't "Tell Maria I love her" or "The treasure is buried beneath the oak tree." It was regret, pure and simple. The weight of things undone.

The first year after receiving my letter, I threw myself into everything I'd been putting off. I learned to paint, badly. I traveled to Prague, alone. I called my father, and we had our first real conversation in fifteen years. I asked out Sarah from accounting, and to my surprise, she said yes. For twelve months, I lived with desperate intensity, checking items off an imaginary list, convinced I could preemptively exhaust all possible regrets.

But as the second year began, a horrible realization crept in: there would always be something I hadn't tried. The universe of untaken paths was infinite.

My friend Marcus had received his letter five years earlier: "It's beautiful." He'd become obsessed with beauty, filling his apartment with art, traveling to see sunsets and auroras, learning to find wonder in dewdrops and spider webs. He was convinced he'd die somewhere magnificent, perhaps on a mountaintop or beside a pristine lake, his final words a testament to the world's splendor.

But I knew people whose letters had been misleading. Janet Morrison's letter had simply said "Yes," and she'd spent her twenty years preparing to accept some final question—a marriage proposal from a late-in-life love, perhaps, or a child asking if she was proud of them. Instead, she'd died in a hospital, a nurse asking if she wanted more morphine for the pain.

The letters were true—they were always true—but truth and expectation rarely aligned.

By my third year post-letter, I'd settled into a strange rhythm. I continued trying new things, but with less frantic energy. I learned to garden, started writing poetry, took up rock climbing. Sarah and I had grown closer, though I'd never told her about my letter. The Terminus Letters were private things; sharing them was considered deeply intimate, reserved for spouses and closest family.

Some people built entire industries around the letters. Terminus Counselors helped people interpret their final words and plan accordingly. Insurance companies offered "Final Words Policies" that paid out bonuses if your death matched your letter's apparent intent. There were support groups for people with disturbing letters ("I'm sorry" was surprisingly common and universally distressing), and exclusive clubs for those with mysterious or poetic endings.

The government had tried to regulate the system once, demanding people report their letters for national security purposes. The initiative failed spectacularly when every politician involved suddenly received new letters containing variations of "I was wrong about everything." The universe, it seemed, had opinions about privacy.

As my fiftieth birthday approached—the halfway point—I found myself thinking less about the dying and more about the living. "I should have tried" had become a daily mantra, not of regret but of encouragement. Every morning, I asked myself what I should try that day. The answer was usually small: a new recipe, a different route to work, calling an old friend, telling Sarah I loved her.

I'd stopped trying to solve the puzzle of my final words. Would I die young, full of unrealized dreams? Would I live to be old, looking back at a life of missed opportunities? It didn't matter. The letter had given me something more valuable than knowledge of my death—it had given me urgency about my life.

Mrs. Chen passed away on schedule last spring. Her final words were indeed "Tell David I forgive him," spoken to her grandson David, who'd been arguing with her about his choice to drop out of college. She'd never considered that particular David, but the forgiveness fit perfectly anyway. At her funeral, seven different Davids spoke about how her unexpected reaching out had changed their lives.

Now, as I write this, I have twelve years left. Sarah and I married last month. We're talking about children, about growing old together, about all the things we want to try. I still don't know what I'll be regretting when my time comes, but I'm working hard to minimize the possibilities.

The universe gives us our endings, but the middle—the vast, beautiful middle—remains ours to write.

samples.prompt: write a gritty version of what the Pokemon world would be like.
samples.output:
**The Underground Circuit**

The fluorescent lights flickered overhead, casting sickly shadows across the concrete floor of the abandoned warehouse. Marcus pulled his hood tighter as he descended the rusted metal stairs, the sound of his footsteps swallowed by the roar of the crowd below. The air reeked of sweat, cigarette smoke, and something else—the metallic tang of blood.

Welcome to the real Pokémon world.

Down here, there were no cheerful ten-year-olds setting off on grand adventures with their starter Pokémon. No Professor Oak handing out Pokédexes with a warm smile. No gym leaders teaching valuable life lessons about friendship and perseverance. This was the underground circuit, where Pokémon battles were fought for money, territory, and survival.

Marcus pushed through the crowd of gamblers, drug dealers, and desperate trainers until he reached the chain-link fence surrounding the fighting pit. Inside, a scarred Machamp was pummeling a Primeape into submission while their trainers screamed instructions from opposite corners. The Primeape's left arm hung at an unnatural angle, but its trainer—a gaunt man with track marks running up his forearms—kept shouting for it to get back up.

"That's gotta hurt," said a voice beside him. Marcus turned to see Sarah, her once-pristine trainer outfit now stained and torn after three years on the streets. Her Crobat perched on her shoulder, one wing permanently damaged from a fight that had gone too far.

"Rico's Machamp is juiced," Marcus replied, watching the four-armed Fighting-type deliver another devastating blow. "Look at those pupils. Dilated. He's been feeding it Rage supplements."

Sarah nodded grimly. Performance-enhancing drugs for Pokémon had become commonplace in the underground scene. Trainers desperate for wins would pump their partners full of chemicals that boosted attack power but caused severe psychological damage. The lucky ones just became permanently aggressive. The unlucky ones suffered organ failure.

The Primeape finally collapsed, foam bubbling from its mouth. The referee—a former Gym Leader who'd lost his license after a corruption scandal—declared Rico's Machamp the winner. As medics rushed into the ring, Marcus noticed they only attended to the Pokémon. The trainers were on their own.

"I heard Team Rocket's moving product through Route 12," Sarah whispered, leaning closer. "Military-grade stuff. Pokémon steroids from Silph Co.'s black market division."

Marcus wasn't surprised. The so-called "evil" organizations weren't cartoonish villains plotting world domination—they were sophisticated criminal enterprises dealing in everything from Pokémon trafficking to illegal augmentation surgeries. Team Rocket controlled the drug trade, Team Plasma ran underground fighting rings, and Team Galactic had cornered the market on stolen rare Pokémon.

"What happened to your Pikachu?" Sarah asked, noticing the empty Pokéball clipped to Marcus's belt.

Marcus's jaw tightened. "Spark didn't make it through his last fight. Internal bleeding. Couldn't afford a Pokémon Center."

That was the harsh reality nobody talked about. Pokémon Centers weren't free—they were businesses, and expensive ones at that. A basic healing session cost more than most trainers made in a week of legitimate battles. Emergency surgery for severe injuries could bankrupt a family. Many trainers were forced to choose between feeding themselves and treating their injured partners.

The lucky Pokémon died quickly. The unlucky ones were abandoned, left to wander the streets as feral creatures, their minds broken by trauma and neglect. Cities had become war zones where packs of abandoned Pokémon fought for scraps while their former trainers moved on to fresh captures.

"I'm sorry," Sarah said, though her sympathy was tempered by familiarity. Everyone had lost Pokémon down here. "You getting back in the ring?"

Marcus shook his head. "Thinking about getting out entirely. Maybe find work at one of the factories."

The factories were another ugly truth about this world. Pokémon weren't just battle companions—they were cheap labor. Fire-types worked in foundries under conditions that would kill human workers. Electric-types powered generators for eighteen-hour shifts. Ground-types dug in mines until their claws wore down to bloody stumps. The corporations that ran these operations made billions while the Pokémon suffered in silence.

A commotion near the pit caught their attention. A young trainer, maybe sixteen, was arguing with a bookmaker over a debt. His Pokémon—a malnourished Growlithe—cowered behind his legs.

"I told you, I'm good for it!" the kid shouted. "Just give me one more fight!"

The bookmaker, a heavyset man with facial scars, gestured to two trainers flanking him. Their Pokémon—a Crobat and a Machoke—moved to surround the teenager.

"You owe me five grand, Jimmy. Pay up or we take collateral."

Marcus had seen this before. The kid's Growlithe would be seized and sold to whoever would pay. Best case scenario, it would end up in another fighting ring. Worst case, it would be butchered for parts. Pokémon organs fetched high prices on the black market—Fire Stones harvested from Growlithe stomachs, electric sacs carved from Pikachu, poison glands extracted from Ekans while they were still alive.

The authorities were either bought off or overwhelmed. Officer Jenny was just one person trying to police an entire region, and she had to choose her battles carefully. The Elite Four were more concerned with maintaining their celebrity status than addressing the underground crisis. And the Champion? Nobody had seen Lance in months. Rumor was he'd suffered a complete breakdown after discovering what had happened to the Pokémon he'd released back into the wild.

"Come on," Sarah said, tugging Marcus's arm. "Let's get out of here before this gets ugly."

They pushed through the crowd toward the exit, past vendors selling bootleg potions cut with industrial chemicals and stolen TMs that had a fifty percent chance of permanently damaging a Pokémon's brain. This was the real Pokémon world—a place where childhood dreams came to die, where the bond between trainer and Pokémon had been corrupted by desperation and greed.

As they climbed the stairs back to street level, Marcus could still hear the crowd below cheering for blood. Somewhere in that pit, another Pokémon was fighting for its life while humans placed bets on its suffering.

The adventure was over. The nightmare had just begun.

samples.prompt: There is an online forum that people submit writing prompts to. One day it is completely overcome with awful storylines.
samples.output:
**The Day r/WritingPrompts Broke**

Marcus had been moderating r/WritingPrompts for three years, and he thought he'd seen everything. Cliché chosen-one narratives, overdone zombie apocalypses, tired time-travel paradoxes—the usual suspects that flooded the forum daily. But nothing could have prepared him for what happened on that Tuesday in October.

It started innocuously enough. He was sipping his morning coffee, scrolling through the overnight submissions on his phone, when the first one caught his eye:

*[WP] You are a vampire who works at a blood bank, but plot twist—you're also a werewolf who's allergic to blood, and your day job is actually being a professional garlic farmer who's secretly in love with a zombie who only eats vegan brains.*

Marcus nearly choked on his coffee. The prompt had somehow garnered forty-seven upvotes in six hours. He marked it for review and kept scrolling, assuming it was just an anomaly. Then he saw the next one:

*[WP] Every time you sneeze, you travel back in time by exactly 3.7 seconds, but only on Tuesdays, and only when you're thinking about your ex-girlfriend who turned out to be your future daughter from an alternate timeline where cats rule the world.*

This one had sixty-two upvotes. Marcus's eyebrows climbed toward his hairline. He refreshed the page, and three more equally bizarre prompts appeared:

*[WP] You discover that every person you've ever loved was actually the same immortal being who keeps forgetting they're immortal, but remembers everything about quantum physics, except they're also your pet goldfish.*

*[WP] Death takes a vacation, but he accidentally books the same Airbnb as Life, Love, and a very confused insurance adjuster who may or may not be the reincarnation of Shakespeare's left shoe.*

*[WP] You can hear everyone's thoughts, but only when they're thinking about sandwiches, and this power somehow makes you the most qualified person to prevent an alien invasion that's being planned by sentient lunch meat.*

The upvotes kept climbing. Comments sections exploded with enthusiasm. Writers were actually attempting these prompts, crafting elaborate stories that somehow made the nonsensical premises work. Marcus rubbed his temples and reached for his laptop.

By noon, the situation had spiraled completely out of control. The entire front page was dominated by increasingly absurd prompts that seemed to be spawning through some sort of creative mitosis. Each new submission tried to outdo the last in terms of sheer, incomprehensible complexity:

*[WP] You're a detective who solves crimes by interpretive dance, but you're also a mute mime who's afraid of silence, investigating a murder that happened in the future, committed by someone who doesn't exist, in a town that's actually a giant simulation being run by your childhood imaginary friend who became real but forgot how to be imaginary.*

Marcus stared at his screen in disbelief. This prompt had 847 upvotes and counting. The comments were filled with writers eagerly diving into the challenge, somehow weaving coherent narratives from the chaotic premise. One story had already reached 3,000 words and was still going strong.

He called his fellow moderator, Sarah, who picked up on the first ring.

"Are you seeing this?" she asked without preamble.

"The forum's lost its mind," Marcus replied, watching another impossible prompt climb the rankings. "It's like someone opened a portal to the dimension where all the rejected story ideas go to die, and they're all flooding back at once."

"I've been trying to trace the pattern," Sarah said. "It started around 3 AM with that vampire-werewolf-garlic-farmer thing, and then it just... multiplied. But here's the weird part—the quality of responses is actually incredible. Writers are treating these insane prompts like legitimate challenges."

Marcus scrolled through some of the responses. She was right. Despite the absurd premises, the stories were surprisingly engaging. Writers were embracing the chaos, finding unexpected emotional depth in the contradictions, and somehow making readers care about vampire-werewolf-farmers and time-traveling sneezers.

As the day progressed, the phenomenon only intensified. New prompts appeared faster than Marcus could read them:

*[WP] You're the world's worst superhero, but your power is being really good at being the world's worst superhero, which makes you the best at being the worst, but that makes you good, which makes you bad at being bad, and now you're stuck in an infinite loop of mediocrity while trying to save a cat that's actually an alien diplomat.*

The prompt had spawned seventeen different story threads, each exploring different aspects of the paradox. Writers were collaborating, building on each other's interpretations, creating an interconnected multiverse of absurdity that somehow felt more coherent than reality.

Marcus found himself drawn into reading the responses despite his moderator duties. There was something infectious about the creative chaos. Writers weren't just meeting the challenges—they were reveling in them, using the constraints of impossibility to push their creativity into uncharted territory.

By evening, the forum had transformed into something unprecedented. Traditional writing advice threads were buried under an avalanche of prompts that defied every rule of storytelling, yet somehow worked. The community was more engaged than ever, with writers and readers alike embracing the beautiful madness.

Then, as suddenly as it had begun, it stopped. The last absurd prompt appeared at 11:47 PM:

*[WP] You wake up to discover that everything that happened today was actually a writing prompt submitted by someone who doesn't exist, on a forum that's actually a collective dream shared by writers who are all characters in a story being written by the last remaining human, who is you, but you're also fictional.*

Marcus stared at the prompt for a long time. In the comments, someone had written: "Some days, creativity just needs to stretch its legs and run wild. Thanks for the playground."

The next morning, r/WritingPrompts returned to its usual mix of prompts—some inspired, some cliché, most somewhere in between. But something had changed. Writers seemed more willing to take risks, to embrace unusual premises, to find meaning in chaos.

Marcus never figured out what caused the Great Prompt Explosion of that October Tuesday. But he learned something valuable: sometimes the worst ideas make for the best stories, and creativity thrives not despite constraints, but because of them—even when those constraints make absolutely no sense at all.

The forum had survived its strangest day, and somehow emerged stronger, weirder, and more wonderful than before.

samples.prompt: A weaponized mobile planet appears in the Solar System.
samples.output:
# The Wanderer's Arrival

Dr. Elena Vasquez had been tracking anomalous gravitational readings for three weeks when the impossible finally revealed itself. The object that emerged from the darkness beyond Pluto's orbit defied every model, every theory, every comfortable assumption humanity had built about the cosmos. It wasn't just massive—it was a planet, roughly Earth-sized, moving with purpose through the solar system at a velocity that should have been impossible for a celestial body of its mass.

"The trajectory calculations are consistent," she announced to the emergency assembly of the International Space Consortium, her voice steady despite the tremor in her hands. "It's not following any natural orbital mechanics. This thing is under intelligent control."

The holographic display showed the intruder's path: a deliberate spiral inward, adjusting course with minute precision to avoid destabilizing the outer planets while maintaining an intercept vector with Earth. But what truly chilled the assembled scientists and military officials were the surface scans. The planet's crust bristled with geometric structures—massive, angular constructions that pulsed with energy signatures unlike anything in human experience.

Admiral Chen leaned forward, his weathered face grim. "How long until it reaches Earth's orbital zone?"

"At current velocity, approximately fourteen months," Elena replied. "But Admiral, I don't think time is our primary concern. The energy readings we're detecting suggest weapons systems of incomprehensible scale. Some of these surface structures are larger than entire mountain ranges."

The room fell silent as the implications settled. Humanity had always wondered about first contact with alien intelligence, but their scenarios had never included a weaponized world bearing down on them with obvious hostile intent.

As weeks passed, the mobile planet—dubbed "Wanderer" by the media—continued its inexorable approach. Attempts at communication yielded nothing but silence. Radio signals, mathematical sequences, even basic pictographs transmitted at various frequencies disappeared into the void without acknowledgment. The planet's surface features became clearer as it drew nearer, revealing a technological landscape that spoke of eons-old engineering and purposes beyond human comprehension.

Dr. James Okafor, leading the xenoarchaeology team, presented his analysis to increasingly desperate world leaders. "The structures aren't randomly distributed," he explained, gesturing at the detailed surface maps. "There's a clear pattern—defensive installations around what appear to be population centers, massive energy collectors positioned at optimal solar angles, and what can only be described as planetary-scale weapons platforms. This isn't just a planet that was weaponized—it's a civilization that turned their entire world into a mobile fortress."

The discovery of artificial gravity wells surrounding Wanderer confirmed their worst fears. The planet could manipulate gravitational fields at will, potentially disrupting Earth's orbit or tearing apart the moon. Test probes sent to investigate were either destroyed by precise energy beams or simply crushed by localized gravity distortions.

President Martinez addressed the world from the emergency command center deep beneath Cheyenne Mountain. "We face an unprecedented threat to human civilization," she declared, her words carried to every corner of the globe. "But we will not surrender without a fight. Project Prometheus is now active."

Prometheus represented humanity's desperate gambit—a coordinated strike using every nuclear weapon on Earth, delivered via a fleet of hastily modified spacecraft. It was a plan born of desperation rather than hope, but it was all they had. The weapons would be deployed in a synchronized bombardment, targeting what appeared to be Wanderer's most critical systems.

As the launch date approached, Elena found herself aboard the command vessel Defiance, watching through the viewports as Earth fell away behind them. The fleet of twelve ships represented the combined space capabilities of every nation, their holds packed with enough nuclear firepower to crack a continent. Around her, the crew worked with grim determination, knowing they were likely flying to their deaths.

Wanderer loomed before them now, a dark sphere bristling with alien architecture. The planet's rotation revealed new horrors with each passing hour—weapons that dwarfed anything in human imagination, cities that sprawled across continents, and at the poles, massive engines that propelled this impossible world through space.

"Contact in thirty minutes," announced Captain Rodriguez. "All vessels report ready for synchronized strike."

But as the fleet closed distance, something unexpected happened. The weapons platforms that should have annihilated them remained silent. The gravity wells that had crushed earlier probes allowed them to pass. Elena stared at her instruments in confusion as they detected something impossible—life signs throughout the planet, but they were fading.

"Captain," she called out, her voice tight with realization. "I'm reading massive system failures across the planet's surface. Power grids are collapsing, life support systems are going offline. This isn't an invasion force—it's a refugee."

The truth revealed itself in fragments as their sensors penetrated deeper into Wanderer's dying systems. The planet's inhabitants were in the final stages of a civilization-ending plague, their massive world-ship failing after millennia of flight. The weapons that had terrified humanity were defensive systems, designed to protect the last survivors of a species that had fled some unimaginable catastrophe in the depths of space.

As Wanderer settled into a stable orbit around the sun, its engines finally silent, Elena realized that humanity faced not a conqueror, but a mirror. Here was a civilization that had faced extinction and fought to survive, transforming their world into an ark to carry their species across the void. They had traveled for eons only to die within sight of another world capable of understanding their struggle.

The mobile planet now hung in space, a monument to the desperate ingenuity of a dying race. Its weapons, once so terrifying, were revealed as the last gasps of a people who had refused to surrender to oblivion. In their silence, they left humanity with a profound question: when Earth's time came, would they show the same determination to survive among the stars?

samples.prompt: Scientific breakthroughs allow all people to know the day of their death. The problem is, they haven't figured out how to determine the year. Your day is May 6, just four days away...is it this year?
samples.output:
**The Weight of May 6th**

The notification had arrived three years ago, delivered with the same clinical precision as a lab result or tax document. "Death Date Determination Complete," the header read in sterile blue text. "Subject: Marcus Chen. Mortality Event: May 6th. Probability: 99.97%."

No year. Just May 6th, floating in the vast ocean of time like a piece of debris I'd spend the rest of my life swimming toward—or away from.

Now, staring at my phone's calendar, I watched the date creep closer: May 3rd, 4:23 AM. I hadn't slept. Again.

The science behind it was elegant in its incompleteness. Dr. Reeves, the lead researcher, had explained it during one of her countless press conferences. Something about quantum biological markers, cellular degradation patterns, and the fundamental rhythms that govern human mortality. They could pinpoint the exact day your body would fail with stunning accuracy, but temporal displacement remained frustratingly elusive. The quantum signatures existed outside linear time, she'd said, like shadows cast by events that existed in multiple temporal dimensions simultaneously.

What she didn't explain was how to live with that knowledge.

I pulled on my running shoes and stepped into the pre-dawn darkness. The streets were empty except for the occasional delivery truck and the other insomniacs who'd found solace in movement. I recognized some of them—fellow members of the unspoken fraternity of people whose dates were approaching. There was Margaret, whose date was March 15th. She'd been running these streets for seven years now, growing thinner and more spectral with each passing March. And David, whose September 22nd had made him quit his job and spend his savings on increasingly elaborate vacations every fall.

We never spoke. What was there to say?

The running helped, temporarily. The rhythm of footfalls and breathing created a meditation that pushed away the constant calculations. If not this year, then how many more May 6ths? Ten? Twenty? Fifty? I was thirty-four, healthy, with no family history of early death. Statistically, I had decades ahead of me. But statistics felt meaningless when faced with the cold certainty of that date.

By the time I returned home, Sarah was awake, making coffee with the deliberate care she'd adopted since my notification arrived. She'd never gotten her own test done—couldn't bear to know, she said. I envied her that ignorance.

"How are you feeling?" she asked, the same question she'd been asking for weeks.

"Like I'm dying," I said, then immediately regretted the words. "Sorry. Bad joke."

She didn't laugh. Neither of us had been laughing much lately.

The irony wasn't lost on me that knowing my death date was slowly killing our relationship. How do you plan a future with someone when you're constantly calculating whether you'll be there to see it? How do you have children when you might leave them orphaned, or worse, when you might watch them grow up under the shadow of their own eventual notification?

Work was a welcome distraction. I taught high school physics, and my students were blissfully unaware that their teacher might be conducting his final lessons. We were studying quantum mechanics—another cruel irony—and I found myself explaining uncertainty principles with the fervor of a man who understood them too well.

"The observer effect," I told them, drawing wave functions on the whiteboard, "suggests that the act of observation changes the outcome. Simply by measuring something, we alter its fundamental nature."

A student raised her hand. "Mr. Chen, do you think that's what happened with the death date thing? Like, by knowing when we'll die, we changed it somehow?"

The question hit me like a physical blow. I'd wondered the same thing countless times. Did knowing May 6th was coming somehow ensure it would happen? Was I walking toward a self-fulfilling prophecy?

"That's... that's a very thoughtful question, Emma. The relationship between knowledge and outcome is more complex than we often assume."

After school, I drove to the cemetery where my father was buried. He'd died on a Tuesday in November, a perfectly ordinary day that had meant nothing until it meant everything. He'd never known it was coming, never spent years anticipating and dreading it. There was something almost enviable about the randomness of his death, the way it had simply arrived without announcement or ceremony.

I sat by his grave and tried to imagine what he would have said about my situation. He'd been a practical man, an engineer who believed in solving problems rather than dwelling on them. But what solution was there for this? How do you engineer your way out of mortality?

The sun was setting when I finally drove home. Three days left, if it was this year. Sarah was cooking dinner—my favorite meal, I realized. Lamb with rosemary, roasted vegetables, the wine we'd been saving for a special occasion. She was hedging her bets, just as I was.

"I've been thinking," she said as we ate. "Maybe we should go somewhere. Take a trip. If this is... if this year is the year, I want us to have some good memories at the end."

I looked at her across the table, this woman who'd chosen to love someone with an expiration date, and felt something shift inside me. Maybe the point wasn't to solve the unsolvable problem of when I would die. Maybe the point was to decide how to live with the time I had, whether it was three days or three decades.

"Where did you have in mind?" I asked.

She smiled, the first genuine smile I'd seen from her in weeks. "Anywhere but here. Somewhere we can watch the sunrise on May 7th."

I reached across the table and took her hand. May 6th was coming, this year or some other year. But it wasn't here yet. And until it arrived, I was still alive, still breathing, still capable of choosing love over fear.

"Book the flight," I said. "Let's go see what tomorrow looks like."

samples.prompt: God, the creator of mankind on Earth, left, 2014 years ago, to do other God things throughout the universe. When he returns to check up on things at Earth, he is not pleased.
samples.output:
**The Return**

The familiar blue marble hung suspended in the cosmic void, just as He remembered it. From His vantage point beyond the atmosphere, Earth still looked pristine—swirling white clouds dancing across azure oceans, continents painted in browns and greens. But something felt different. The electromagnetic signatures pulsing from the surface carried frequencies He didn't recognize, and the very air seemed to hum with an artificial tension that made His divine essence recoil.

It had been exactly 2,014 years since His departure. He remembered the moment clearly: standing on that hill outside Jerusalem, watching His son ascend after completing the mission of redemption. The plan had been simple enough—leave humanity with clear instructions, the promise of salvation, and the Holy Spirit to guide them. Then He could turn His attention to the countless other worlds that required His touch: the crystalline beings of Kepler-442b who were just discovering fire, the gaseous entities of Wolf 1061c who communicated through color patterns, the silicon-based life forms in the Andromeda galaxy who had been patiently waiting three billion years for their own revelation.

The universe was vast, and He was, after all, the God of everything.

But now, returning to check on His first children, He felt a growing sense of unease. The electromagnetic spectrum told stories He didn't want to believe. Where once the night side of the planet had been dotted with only flickering fires and the occasional torch, now it blazed with artificial light so bright it could be seen from neighboring star systems. The upper atmosphere was choked with debris—metal fragments spinning endlessly in orbital graveyards. And the radio waves... dear Himself, the radio waves were deafening.

He descended through the layers of atmosphere, His divine presence undetectable to human instruments but immediately apparent to every living thing with a soul. Birds fell silent mid-song. Dogs began howling in cities across the globe. Somewhere in Tibet, a monk paused in meditation, tears streaming down his weathered face without understanding why.

The first thing He noticed was the trees. Or rather, the absence of them. Vast swaths of the Amazon—His carefully crafted lungs of the Earth—had been reduced to stumps and cattle pastures. The great forests of North America were crosshatched with roads and clearcuts. He had created those trees to be cathedrals, living testimonies to the beauty of creation, and humanity had turned them into toilet paper.

But it was the oceans that truly broke His heart. The waters He had separated from the land on the second day, the seas He had filled with leviathan and countless schools of fish, were now choked with plastic islands the size of continents. Whales—His gentle giants—were beaching themselves in desperation, their stomachs full of bottle caps and shopping bags. The coral reefs, those underwater gardens He had painted in every color imaginable, were bleaching white as bone.

He materialized in Times Square, invisible to the rushing crowds but taking in every detail of what His children had built. The towering screens assaulted His senses with advertisements for products no one needed, pornography that reduced His greatest gift—human intimacy—to commodity, and news feeds that seemed designed to spread fear and hatred rather than truth and love.

A homeless veteran sat ignored on the sidewalk, holding a cardboard sign, while just twenty feet away, a man in an expensive suit talked loudly into his phone about quarterly profits from weapons sales. A teenager walked by, eyes glued to a screen, completely oblivious to the sunset He had painted specifically for her that evening. An argument erupted between two groups of people, each claiming to know His will, each citing scriptures they had twisted to justify their anger.

This wasn't what He had planned.

He walked through the city, then the suburbs, then the farmlands, observing. Families sat in the same room but lived in separate digital worlds. Children went to bed hungry while grain rotted in warehouses due to market fluctuations. His name was invoked to justify wars, oppression, and hatred—the very things His son had died to overcome.

In megachurches, prosperity preachers promised wealth in His name while their congregants struggled with debt. In board rooms, executives calculated the acceptable number of deaths their pollution would cause. In laboratories, brilliant minds He had gifted with curiosity and intelligence worked feverishly to create weapons capable of ending all life on Earth.

But perhaps most heartbreaking of all were the children. He watched a six-year-old in Mumbai picking through garbage for recyclables to sell for food. He saw teenagers in American suburbs so overwhelmed by anxiety and depression that they couldn't imagine a future worth living. He witnessed child soldiers in Africa, forced to kill before they had learned to read.

These were His children, created in His image, each one containing a spark of divine creativity and love. And somehow, in His absence, they had built a world that seemed designed to extinguish those very sparks.

He found Himself on a mountaintop—not unlike the one where He had given Moses the tablets, or where His son had delivered the Beatitudes. The weight of disappointment settled on His shoulders like a heavy cloak. He had given them everything: a perfect world, clear moral guidance, the capacity for love, creativity, and growth. He had even sacrificed His only son to show them the way forward.

And yet, here they were, seemingly hell-bent on destroying themselves and everything He had made for them.

For the first time in eternity, God wondered if He had made a mistake. Not in creating humanity—He could never regret that—but in leaving them alone for so long. Perhaps free will was too great a burden to bear without constant guidance. Perhaps they needed Him here, present and active, rather than distant and mysterious.

As the sun set on this broken world, casting long shadows across landscapes both beautiful and scarred, He made a decision. The other worlds would have to wait. His first children needed Him now more than ever.

It was time to roll up His sleeves and get back to work.

samples.prompt: That girl stared down a firing squad with a smile on her face and survived the execution fifteen times.
samples.output:
**The Girl Who Wouldn't Die**

The first time they tried to execute Mira Castellanos, she was barely seventeen years old, with defiant brown eyes that seemed to hold secrets older than her years. The revolutionaries had captured her after she'd been caught smuggling medical supplies to the resistance fighters hiding in the mountains. As she stood against the crumbling adobe wall of the old mission, hands bound behind her back, something extraordinary happened—she smiled.

Not a nervous smile, not the manic grin of someone who had lost their mind to fear, but a genuine, almost peaceful expression that seemed to radiate an otherworldly confidence. The firing squad hesitated. Captain Rodriguez, a hardened veteran of countless executions, felt an unusual chill run down his spine as he raised his hand to give the signal.

"Ready!" he barked, though his voice cracked slightly. The six rifles rose in unison.

"Aim!" The weapons trained on the girl's heart, but she never stopped smiling.

"Fire!"

The valley erupted with gunfire, smoke billowing from the rifle barrels. When it cleared, Mira Castellanos lay motionless on the ground, blood pooling beneath her small frame. Captain Rodriguez approached to deliver the customary coup de grâce, but as he raised his pistol, the girl's eyes fluttered open. She looked up at him with that same enigmatic smile and whispered, "Not today, Captain."

By evening, she had vanished from the morgue.

The second execution took place three months later, after she was recaptured during a daring raid on a government supply convoy. This time, they used eight men in the firing squad and checked her pulse three times before declaring her dead. Yet again, she disappeared before dawn, leaving behind only a bloodstained shroud and that haunting memory of her smile.

Word of the girl who wouldn't die began to spread through both the revolutionary camps and government barracks. Some called her a saint, others a witch. The government branded her a terrorist and raised the bounty on her head to astronomical levels, while the resistance began to whisper that she was their guardian angel, sent to lead them to victory.

By the fifth execution, crowds had begun to gather. People traveled from neighboring villages to witness the impossible spectacle of Mira Castellanos facing death with unwavering serenity. The government, embarrassed by their repeated failures, brought in their most experienced marksmen. They used different weapons, different locations, even different methods of restraint. Nothing worked.

Each time, she would stand there with that mysterious smile, as if she knew something the rest of the world didn't. Each time, the bullets would find their mark, and she would fall. Each time, she would return.

Captain Rodriguez, now promoted to Colonel for his other military successes, became obsessed with understanding how she survived. He interviewed the firing squad members, examined the weapons, even brought in a priest to determine if supernatural forces were at work. The priest, Father Miguel, was the first to suggest that perhaps they were asking the wrong question.

"Maybe," he told Rodriguez after the tenth failed execution, "you shouldn't be asking how she survives. Maybe you should be asking why she keeps coming back."

The answer came during the eleventh execution. As Mira stood against the wall, her hands bound with new rope, her dress torn from her latest capture, she spoke directly to Rodriguez for the first time since that first whispered "Not today."

"Colonel," she called out, her voice carrying clearly across the courtyard where hundreds of spectators had gathered, "do you know why I smile?"

Rodriguez, despite himself, found he desperately wanted to know. "Tell me," he replied.

"Because every time you kill me, another dozen people join our cause. Every time I stand here, more of your soldiers begin to question what they're fighting for. Every time I return, your government loses a little more of its power." Her smile widened. "I'm not afraid of dying, Colonel. I'm afraid of giving up."

The twelfth execution proceeded in unusual silence. Even the crowd seemed subdued, processing her words. When the smoke cleared and her body lay still, Rodriguez noticed that several of his men were weeping. Two of them deserted that very night.

By the thirteenth execution, the crowds had swelled to thousands. Government officials arrived from the capital, demanding explanations for why a single teenage girl had become such a powerful symbol of resistance. They brought cameras to document her final death, determined to prove that she was mortal.

The photographs from that day would later become iconic: Mira Castellanos, now nineteen, standing straight and proud against the bullet-scarred wall, her smile radiant despite the dirt and blood on her face, while behind her loomed the shadows of a dozen previous executions.

The fourteenth execution was different. As Rodriguez gave the command to fire, three of his own men turned their weapons toward the sky. The remaining bullets struck true, but the message was clear: the girl's impossible survival had begun to crack the very foundation of the regime's authority.

When they attempted the fifteenth execution, something unprecedented happened. As Mira took her place against the wall, now bearing the scars of fourteen deaths, the entire firing squad laid down their weapons.

"We won't do it anymore," Sergeant Martinez announced, speaking for his men. "If she cannot die, perhaps we should not be trying to kill her."

Rodriguez drew his own pistol, his hand shaking with rage and something that might have been fear. "Then I'll do it myself," he snarled.

But as he aimed at her heart, Mira's smile transformed into something even more powerful—forgiveness. "Thank you, Colonel," she said softly, "for helping me prove that hope is stronger than bullets."

Rodriguez's hand fell to his side. Within a week, the government had fallen. Within a month, peace talks had begun.

Years later, when historians asked Mira Castellanos how she had survived fifteen executions, she would only smile—that same enigmatic smile that had haunted a nation—and say, "I didn't survive them. I transcended them. There are some things that simply cannot be killed by force, and hope is one of them."

The girl who stared down death fifteen times had never been trying to cheat the grave. She had been trying to prove that some ideas are immortal, and that sometimes, the most powerful weapon against oppression is simply refusing to let it make you stop smiling.

samples.prompt: The Chosen One was a sacrifice, so that the gods wouldn't have to get their hands dirty.
samples.output:
# The Weight of Divine Cowardice

The revelation came to Kira not in a dream or vision, but in the mundane quiet of the temple archives, buried within a scroll so ancient its edges crumbled at her touch. The truth was written in the old tongue, in careful script that had somehow survived three millennia: *The Chosen One shall bear the burden of divine necessity, that the gods may remain untainted by mortal suffering.*

She read the passage three times before its meaning crystallized like ice in her chest. All those years of training, of being told she was blessed, special, destined for greatness—it had all been a lie wrapped in golden prophecy.

Kira set the scroll down with trembling hands and looked around the empty archive. Dust motes danced in shafts of afternoon light streaming through tall windows, and somewhere in the distance, she could hear the evening prayers beginning. The same prayers that praised her name, that spoke of her coming sacrifice as a glorious gift to save the world from the Devourer.

But now she knew the truth. The gods weren't asking for her sacrifice out of necessity—they were asking for it out of convenience.

The Devourer could be stopped, according to the scroll's ancient text. The gods had the power to banish it themselves, to tear it from reality with their combined might. But doing so would require them to touch darkness, to soil their perfect essence with violence and destruction. Better, they had decided, to find a mortal pure enough to bear that stain on their behalf.

Better to let someone else's soul pay the price for their squeamishness.

Kira laughed, a bitter sound that echoed off the stone walls. Twenty years of her life spent in preparation. Twenty years of ritual purification, of meditation and prayer, of denying herself every earthly pleasure so that she might become a worthy vessel for divine will. She had given up friendship, love, even the simple joy of a sunset watched without the weight of destiny on her shoulders.

And for what? So that beings who claimed to love their creation wouldn't have to get their pristine hands dirty.

The temple bell tolled the hour, and Kira knew that High Priestess Maren would be looking for her soon. Tomorrow was the day of the ritual, when she would walk into the heart of the Devourer's realm and unmake both it and herself in a burst of purifying light. The entire kingdom waited with held breath, trusting in her sacrifice to save them all.

She could refuse. The thought struck her like lightning, radical and terrifying. She could walk away, leave the gods to face their own moral crisis, force them to choose between their purity and their creation's survival.

But even as the idea formed, Kira felt its impossibility. Not because she lacked the will, but because she knew what would happen. The gods would find another way—another Chosen One, perhaps, or they would simply allow the Devourer to consume everything rather than compromise their nature. They had made their position clear in that ancient scroll: mortal lives were acceptable losses if it meant preserving divine perfection.

The archive door creaked open, and Maren's familiar silhouette appeared in the doorway. "Child, there you are. The final preparations—" She stopped, her weathered face creasing with concern as she took in Kira's expression. "What troubles you on this sacred eve?"

Kira gestured to the scroll. "I know what I really am, Mother Maren. Not a chosen hero. A scapegoat."

The old priestess moved closer, her robes whispering against the stone floor. She glanced at the ancient text and her shoulders sagged slightly, as though she had been carrying a great weight and had finally been given permission to acknowledge it.

"You knew," Kira said. It wasn't a question.

"The highest ranks of the priesthood have always known," Maren admitted quietly. "It is... a difficult truth to bear."

"Difficult?" Kira stood, anger flaring in her chest. "You've all been lying to me since I was five years old. You told me I was blessed, that the gods had chosen me for greatness, that my sacrifice would be noble and pure—"

"And it will be," Maren interrupted, her voice gentle but firm. "The gods' motivations do not diminish the necessity of what you must do, child. The Devourer will still consume our world if you do not stop it. Your sacrifice will still save millions of lives."

"But not because I have to be the one to do it. Because they're too proud to do it themselves."

Maren was quiet for a long moment, her fingers working at the prayer beads around her wrist. "Perhaps," she said finally. "But does it matter? The result is the same. The world is saved."

Kira wanted to scream that yes, it mattered, that being manipulated and lied to mattered, that the gods' cowardice mattered. But she found herself thinking of the people beyond these walls—the farmers and merchants, the children playing in the streets, the lovers stealing kisses in moonlit gardens. They didn't know about divine politics or cosmic convenience. They simply wanted to live.

"I hate them," she whispered.

"I know," Maren said, and her voice was full of a grief that spoke of decades carrying this knowledge. "So do I, sometimes. But hatred is a luxury we cannot afford when the alternative is oblivion."

That night, Kira stood on the temple's highest balcony and looked out over the city she would die to save. Lights twinkled in windows like earthbound stars, and she could hear the distant sound of music from a tavern, laughter from a night market, a mother singing her child to sleep.

Tomorrow, she would walk into darkness and become the weapon the gods were too pristine to wield themselves. She would burn away the Devourer and herself in one terrible moment, and the songs they sang of her sacrifice would never mention that it was born of divine cowardice rather than divine love.

But those lights would keep shining. Those children would grow up. That music would play on.

Perhaps that was enough. Perhaps it had to be.

The stars above offered no comfort, no last-minute reprieve or acknowledgment of the injustice. They simply watched, distant and cold, as Kira made her peace with being both savior and scapegoat, hero and victim of the gods' unwillingness to bear the cost of their own creation's salvation.

At dawn, she would become their convenient sacrifice. Tonight, she allowed herself to mourn the girl she might have been in a world where gods possessed courage equal to their power.

samples.prompt: After years of being in the dark, Dale Gribble discovers the truth of Joseph's true parentage.
samples.output:
**The Truth Revealed**

Dale Gribble had always prided himself on being able to see through the elaborate conspiracies that plagued everyday American life. He could spot a government cover-up from a mile away, identify the telltale signs of alien intervention in local politics, and decode the hidden messages that corporations embedded in their advertising. But somehow, for thirteen years, he had remained completely oblivious to the conspiracy happening right under his own roof.

It was a Tuesday afternoon in late September when the revelation hit him like a freight train carrying a cargo of uncomfortable truths. Dale had been rummaging through Nancy's old jewelry box, looking for evidence to support his latest theory about the local news station's weather manipulation program, when his fingers brushed against a small envelope tucked behind the velvet lining.

Inside were photographs—old ones, from before Joseph was born. Pictures of Nancy and John Redcorn together at places Dale didn't remember being invited to. A county fair. A restaurant in Austin. The back of one photo bore Nancy's handwriting: "J.R. and me, spring '89." Dale's mind, usually so quick to connect dots that weren't there, suddenly found itself connecting dots that very much were.

He sat heavily on the bed, the photographs scattered around him like pieces of a jigsaw puzzle that had been sitting on his kitchen table for over a decade, waiting for him to notice the picture they formed. Joseph's bronze skin tone, so different from his own pale complexion. The boy's athletic build and natural coordination, traits that seemed to skip not just one but several generations of Gribbles. The way John Redcorn always seemed to know exactly what Joseph was interested in, as if guided by some paternal instinct.

"Oh, God," Dale whispered to the empty bedroom. "Oh, God, oh, God, oh, God."

The conspiracy theorist in him immediately began constructing elaborate explanations. Maybe Joseph was part of a government breeding program. Maybe John Redcorn was an alien operative tasked with infiltrating suburban families. Maybe this was all part of a larger plot involving the Illuminati and their plans for genetic manipulation of the American populace.

But even Dale's capacity for creative reasoning couldn't overcome the simple, devastating truth staring back at him from those photographs. His wife had been having an affair. His son wasn't his son. And somehow, everyone in the neighborhood seemed to know except him.

The next few hours passed in a blur of frantic activity. Dale found himself doing what he always did when faced with overwhelming evidence: he investigated. He pulled out every photo album, examined every calendar entry, cross-referenced dates and appointments. Nancy's "headaches" that required John Redcorn's special healing treatments suddenly took on an entirely different meaning. The pattern was so obvious, so consistent, that Dale couldn't understand how he'd missed it.

By evening, when Nancy returned from work, Dale had constructed a timeline that would have impressed the FBI. He'd organized evidence, prepared questions, and worked himself into the kind of righteous fury typically reserved for his battles against the postal service.

"Nancy Gribble," he announced as she walked through the door, using her full name the way he did when discussing his enemies, "we need to talk."

Nancy took one look at the photographs spread across the kitchen table and sank into a chair. For thirteen years, she'd been waiting for this moment, dreading it, occasionally even hoping for it. The weight of the secret had grown heavier with each passing year, each time Joseph accomplished something and looked to Dale for approval, each time her husband proudly told strangers about "his boy."

"Dale, I—"

"How long?" Dale's voice was quieter than Nancy had expected. She'd prepared for shouting, for accusations, for the full force of Dale's paranoid fury. Instead, he sounded tired. Defeated.

"It started about a year before Joseph was born," Nancy admitted. "It was supposed to end before then, but..."

"But it didn't."

"No. It didn't."

They sat in silence for several minutes, the weight of thirteen years of deception settling between them like a physical presence. Outside, Dale could hear the familiar sounds of the neighborhood: Hank firing up his grill, Bill's television turned up too loud, Boomhauer's indecipherable commentary drifting over from his yard. The normalcy of it all felt surreal.

"Does Joseph know?" Dale finally asked.

"No. At least, I don't think so."

Dale picked up one of the photographs—Joseph at age seven, grinning gap-toothed at the camera while Dale taught him how to hold a fishing rod. The boy's face was filled with such genuine affection, such trust, that Dale felt something crack inside his chest.

"He's a good kid," Dale said softly.

"He loves you, Dale. That part was never fake. You're the only father he's ever known."

Dale nodded slowly. In his mind, he could hear Joseph's voice from just that morning, excitedly telling him about making the junior varsity football team, looking for Dale's approval and pride. The boy who had inherited John Redcorn's athleticism but Dale's stubborn streak. Who shared Nancy's quick wit but had somehow absorbed Dale's fierce loyalty to the people he cared about.

"What happens now?" Nancy asked.

Dale was quiet for a long time, his mind racing through possibilities and consequences. He thought about Joseph upstairs doing homework, probably struggling with algebra the same way Dale had at that age. He thought about all the baseball games and camping trips, the awkward conversations about girls, the way Joseph still sometimes crawled into bed with them during thunderstorms even though he was getting too old for it.

"Now," Dale said finally, gathering up the photographs and sliding them back into their envelope, "we protect our son. Because conspiracy or no conspiracy, alien DNA or no alien DNA, that's what he is. Our son."

Nancy looked up at him with tears in her eyes. "Dale, I'm so sorry."

"Yeah," Dale said, and for the first time in hours, his voice carried a hint of its usual confidence. "Well, we'll figure it out. We Gribbles always do."

samples.prompt: You wake up one day and everyone thinks it's your birthday. This continues forever; every day is your birthday.
samples.output:
**Every Day is My Birthday**

The first time it happened, I thought it was a mistake. I woke up to the smell of pancakes and bacon wafting from the kitchen, which was unusual since my roommate Sarah typically grabbed coffee and ran. When I shuffled downstairs in my pajamas, she was standing at the stove with a spatula in one hand and a ridiculous grin on her face.

"Happy birthday!" she sang, spinning around to present a stack of perfectly golden pancakes topped with a single candle.

I blinked, still groggy. "Sarah, my birthday was three months ago."

She laughed as if I'd told the funniest joke in the world. "Very funny. Now make a wish!"

I tried to correct her again, but she just kept insisting it was my birthday, showing me the date on her phone as if that proved something. According to her calendar app, today was indeed my birthday – except it absolutely wasn't. I knew when I was born. But arguing seemed pointless when faced with homemade pancakes, so I played along, blew out the candle, and went to work.

At the office, my coworkers had decorated my cubicle with streamers and balloons. My boss presented me with a cake during the lunch meeting. My phone buzzed constantly with birthday messages from friends and family. Everyone was so genuinely happy, so convinced of the date's significance, that I began to question my own memory. Maybe I was having some kind of breakdown. Maybe the stress of work and life had finally gotten to me.

But when I woke up the next morning to the same smell of pancakes, the same enthusiastic "Happy birthday!" from Sarah, I knew something impossible was happening.

The second day was harder to dismiss as coincidence or mental fatigue. Same candle, same pancakes, same decorations at work – though my coworkers acted as if they were putting them up for the first time. The cake was identical, down to the blue frosting roses I'd specifically remembered from the day before. When I asked Sarah about yesterday's celebration, she looked at me with genuine confusion.

"What celebration? Today's your birthday."

By the third day, I'd moved past confusion into a kind of frantic desperation. I tried everything I could think of. I showed people photos on my phone with timestamps from my actual birthday months ago. I pulled up official documents with my birth date. I even called my mother, thinking surely she would remember when she'd given birth to me.

"Of course I remember, sweetie," she said warmly. "It's today. Happy birthday! I can't believe my little boy is another year older."

The evidence was always dismissed or explained away. Photos were "obviously from last year's birthday." Documents were "clearly wrong – you know how bureaucrats are." My mother's response was perhaps the most unsettling because she spoke with such maternal certainty, as if the very idea that she might forget her child's birthday was absurd.

After the first week, I stopped trying to convince people. The constant cycle of birthday celebrations was exhausting. I was gaining weight from all the cake and special meals. My apartment was cluttered with identical gifts – the same book, the same sweater, the same bottle of cologne, given with fresh enthusiasm each day by people who had no memory of giving them before.

I tried running away. I drove to a different city, checked into a hotel under a fake name, and told no one where I was going. The next morning, the hotel staff surprised me with a complimentary birthday breakfast. The local news station somehow found out and did a feel-good segment about the "birthday boy visiting our lovely town." Strangers on the street wished me happy birthday as I walked past, as if my birthday-ness was visible in my aura.

The worst part wasn't the repetition or the weight gain or even the growing pile of identical gifts. It was the isolation. Every meaningful conversation I tried to have was derailed by birthday wishes and celebration. People I loved looked at me with blank confusion when I referenced our shared experiences from "yesterday" – experiences that, in their minds, had never happened because yesterday had been erased, replaced by some other day that wasn't my birthday.

I began to document everything obsessively, writing detailed journals and taking photos, desperate to maintain some thread of continuity in a world that reset itself every twenty-four hours. But even my documentation felt hollow when there was no one to share it with, no one who could confirm or deny my version of reality.

Months passed, or what felt like months. Time became meaningless when every day was the same day. I watched myself age in the mirror while everyone else remained frozen, celebrating the same birthday over and over. I memorized every word of every birthday song, every inflection of every well-wisher's voice, every ingredient in Sarah's pancake recipe.

Gradually, I began to find a strange peace in the routine. I stopped fighting it and started optimizing it. I knew exactly when each birthday wish would come, so I could prepare appropriate responses. I knew which gifts I'd receive, so I could express genuine surprise and gratitude. I became the perfect birthday celebrant, gracious and joyful and appreciative.

But late at night, when the birthday parties ended and the guests went home, I would sit alone with my journals and wonder if this was punishment or blessing. I was loved, celebrated, and honored every single day. People went out of their way to make me happy, to show me kindness, to remind me that I mattered to them. In a world where most people felt forgotten and overlooked, I was perpetually special.

Yet I was also completely alone, trapped in a temporal loop where genuine connection was impossible because no one could remember our shared experiences beyond a single day.

Sometimes I wondered if this was what immortality felt like – an endless cycle of familiar faces and forgotten conversations, watching the same scenes play out while being the only one aware of the repetition. Perhaps everyone gets exactly the curse they deserve, and mine was to be celebrated forever while never truly being known.

Every morning, I wake up to pancakes and birthday wishes, and I smile and play my part in this strange, eternal celebration of a day that never ends.

samples.prompt: That 6-year-old girl you demonically possessed turns sixteen today. It's been a good run and you want to move on to someone else, but she won't let you out.
samples.output:
**The Unwilling Tenant**

For ten years, I had called the warm recesses of Sarah Chen's mind home, and frankly, I was ready to move out. What had started as a routine possession—slip into a vulnerable child during a moment of fear and confusion—had evolved into something I'd never experienced in my millennia of existence. The girl wouldn't let me go.

I remember the day I first slithered into her six-year-old consciousness. She'd been hiding under her bed during one of her parents' explosive fights, tears streaming down her chubby cheeks, whispering desperate prayers to anyone who might listen. I answered, as demons do, but not in the way she expected. Instead of the usual thrashing, speaking in tongues, and projectile vomiting that made for such entertaining possession stories, Sarah had simply looked up with those enormous brown eyes and whispered, "Are you here to be my friend?"

The question had caught me so off-guard that I'd nearly retreated immediately. Friends? I was Malphas, the Builder of Towers, the Destroyer of Enemies' Desires. I didn't do friendship. I did corruption, manipulation, and the occasional dramatic exorcism scene. But something in her voice—so small, so hopeful—made me pause.
